title-group.article-title: Identifying spatial variation, individual and community-level determinants affecting quality of antenatal care among women in sub-Saharan Africa: evidence from nationally representative cross-sectional surveys

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics, University of Gondar, Gondar, Ethiopia
2Department of Human Physiology, University of Gondar, Gondar, Ethiopia
3Department of Anesthesia, University of Gondar, Gondar, Ethiopia
4Department of Biomedical Sciences, Madda Walabu University, Robe, Ethiopia
5Department of Anatomy, University of Gondar, Gondar, Ethiopia
6Department of Reproductive Health, University of Gondar, Gondar, Ethiopia

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: Using nationally representative data, this study aimed to examine spatial variation, and individual and community-level determinants influencing the quality of antenatal care (ANC) services among women in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA).

sec.title: Design
sec.p: A community-based cross-sectional study was conducted using the data from a recent Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) of 31 sub-Saharan African countries. A total weighted sample of 204 776 women aged 15–49 years who had ANC visits for their last child was included in this study. The quality of ANC was assessed using six essential components: blood pressure measurement, blood sample test, urine sample test, tetanus toxoid vaccination, iron supplementation and administration of antiparasitic medications. Finally, we employed multilevel analysis to detect the association between determinant variables and the quality of ANC services.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: This study was conducted over 31 sub-Saharan African countries with recent DHS.

sec.title: Outcome variable
sec.p: Received good quality of ANC services (yes/ no).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Only 15.0% (95% CI: 12.0% to 18.0%) of the women in SSA received good-quality ANC services, which varied from 1% (95% CI: 0.0 to 1.0) in Zimbabwe to 41.0% (95% CI: 40.0 to 43.0) in Zambia. Blood pressure measurement is the most offered component (88.1%), and the least offered component of ANC was the provision of tetanus vaccination (44.8%). Factors associated with higher odds of the quality of ANC included age 24–35 years and ≥35 years, attending secondary education, having mass media exposure, those in the richer wealth quintile, having four or more ANC contacts, timely ANC initiation, residing in urban areas, women from a community with high education and women from a community with high media exposure.

sec.title: Conclusion and recommendation
sec.p: This study showed a low proportion of women who received quality ANC in SSA. Both individual and community-level factors play a crucial role in determining the quality of ANC. Therefore, we recommended to upgrade the quality of ANC in SSA by improving women’s education, increasing access to mass media exposure, enhancing timely initiation of ANC and increasing the frequency of ANC contacts, which are vital.

caption.title: STRENGTHS AND LIMITATIONS OF THIS STUDY

list-item.p: This study utilises multiple Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) across sub-Saharan Africa, enhancing the generalisability of the findings across a broad population.

By identifying geographical variations, the study provides critical insights into regional disparities in antenatal care (ANC) quality, which can inform targeted public health interventions to improve maternal health services and reduce inequalities.

However, the cross-sectional nature of DHS data means that causality is not inferred, and the DHS surveys were conducted in different years across sub-Saharan African countries, which might affect comparability of ANC quality over time.
Data on ANC were collected by self-reported and this may lead to recall bias, particularly regarding timing and components of care received.

Additionally, the DHS dataset provides more comprehensive information; it may miss important contextual factors such as health worker quality, facility readiness and cultural practices that may significantly affect the quality of ANC services.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Antenatal care (ANC) is one of the recommended interventions to reduce maternal, newborn and child mortalities and stillbirths through early identification and management of pregnancy complications or pre-existing conditions.1 2 While the percentage of women attending at least one ANC visit is relatively high even in low-income countries, in most sub-Saharan African countries, maternal and neonatal mortality remains high.35 Although approximately 87% of pregnant women in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) access ANC, only 58.5% of pregnant women in SSA used the recommended ANC services (≥4 ANC contacts).3 6 Hence, to ensure the ANC visits truly effective, it is essential that the full range of recommended contents and services is provided.7

Quality of ANC is the most vital issue and a key predictor of health outcomes in low-income as well as high-income countries, playing a central role in achieving Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).8 Good quality of ANC, involving investigations and interventions by a health professional on pregnant women, is essential in averting maternal and neonatal morbidity, mortality and stillbirths.1 Evidence shows that the quality of ANC can reduce the risk of stillbirth by nearly 50% and neonatal mortality by 39%.9 10 Similarly, increased coverage and quality of maternal healthcare could prevent 71% of neonatal deaths, 54% of maternal deaths and 33% of stillbirths in low-income and middle-income countries (LMICs).11

The quality of ANC is typically assessed by three dimensions: the number of ANC visits, the timing of the first ANC visit and the inclusion of all recommended components of care.12 While numerous studies have explored the first two aspects,31317 there is limited conceptual and empirical research focusing on the quality or content of ANC in SSA. Although strategies for ANC content vary across countries, the WHO recommends that every pregnant woman receive a standard package of services during ANC contact. This package includes blood pressure measurement, tetanus toxoid vaccination, urine testing, iron tablet supplementation, deworming after the first trimester, blood sample analysis and counselling on danger signs.18

Monitoring blood pressure during pregnancy is a critical strategy for the early detection and management of hypertensive disorders.19 Urine testing supports the timely diagnosis, prevention and treatment of conditions such as urinary tract infections, gestational diabetes and pre-eclampsia.19 20 Tetanus vaccination during ANC is highly effective in preventing maternal and neonatal tetanus, thereby safeguarding the health of mothers and newborns.21 Blood sample provision helps for early screening and prompt management of anaemia, malaria, hepatitis B, syphilis and HIV.2225 The administration of antiparasitic medications helps to treat maternal infections that may affect fetal health, especially in helminth’s endemic areas.26 Iron supplementation plays a vital role in preventing anaemia, thereby reducing the risk of preterm births, low birth weight and maternal mortality.22 27

Previous studies based on country-specific demographic surveys have identified various factors associated with the quality of ANC including women’s educational status,712 2831 place of residence,718 3133 parity,12 18 30 34 media exposure,12 18 31 age,28 31 wealth status,17 18 3133 number of ANC visits,730 3236 the timing of first ANC visit,29 32 33 unwanted pregnancy,18 34 place of ANC visit,7 18 33 history of stillbirth,35 employment status/occupation1 34 and distance from a health facility.28 37

Despite the SDGs 4 and 5 targeting to reduce neonatal mortality to 12 per 1000 live births and maternal mortality rate to less than 70 per 100 000 live births with no country exceeding over 140 per 100 000 live births by 2030,38 SSA continues to bear the highest burden of maternal mortality globally. In 2017, SSA accounted for approximately 66% of the estimated global maternal deaths, with a rate of 542 deaths per 100 000 live births, compared with a global average of 216 per 100 000.5 39

Also, there are country-specific studies exploring the quality of ANC and its determinants in the sub-Saharan African region1 20 30 40; there is no pooled evidence of the quality of ANC using nationally representative data. Additionally, only limited studies examined the influence of community-level variables on the quality of ANC. Understanding these factors and providing community-based interventions can play a role in identifying high-risk pregnancies early and preventing complications during pregnancy, childbirth and the postpartum period.

Therefore, this study addresses these gaps by using nationally representative survey data to investigate geographic variation, and individual and community-level determinants affecting the quality of ANC among pregnant women in SSA. The findings of this study have significant implications for advancing the SDGs 3, which aims to ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages, particularly maternal and child health outcomes in the region.

sec.title: Study design and study settings
sec.p: This study relies on secondary data from Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) conducted in SSA. The DHS is a cross-sectional nationally representative survey undertaken across LMICs.

sec.title: Data source
sec.p: This study analysed data from the recent (2010–2022) DHS conducted in 31 sub-Saharan African countries. The DHS surveys follow the same standard procedure of sampling, questionnaires, data collection and coding. This consistency of the survey method over time and across countries makes multicountry analysis simple and reasonable. Therefore, datasets were appended together to explore the quality of ANC and its determinants among pregnant women in SSA. It measures key indicators that are considered important to allow countries to generate data that can be used to inform policy and practice.

To assure national representativeness, the survey employs a two-stage sampling procedure that involves the selection of census enumeration areas from each sampling stratum using a probability proportional to the size of the number of households in each enumeration area in the first stage. In the second stage, households are sampled using systematic random sampling from each enumeration area, which forms the survey clusters. A detailed description of the DHS sampling design and data collection procedures can be found elsewhere.41 Furthermore, the DHS dataset is freely available at https://dhsprogram.com/data/available-datasets.cfm.

sec.title: Study population and sampling procedure
sec.p: A total of 438 449 women of reproductive age (15–49 years) were interviewed in 31 sub-Saharan African countries. The target population of this study was women of reproductive age who have under-five children and who had ANC visits for their last child. Therefore, the pooled total weighted sample size of study participants was 204 776 (figure 1) and the total number of study participants from each country ranged from 1882 in Comoros to 16 575 in Nigeria (table 1).

caption.title: Descriptive summary of year of survey and sample of all countries included in the study
Flow chart for country selection and data extraction.

sec.title: Outcome variable
sec.p: The main outcome variable in this secondary data analysis was the quality of ANC, which was measured by the content of care received during ANC. Six essential components of ANC services were included in this study: blood pressure measurement, a blood sample taken, a urine sample taken, tetanus toxoid vaccination, iron supplementation and antiparasitic drugs taken. The quality of ANC was measured as a composite variable and had zero and 6 minimum and maximum scores, respectively. If the women scored zero, they did not use any services and if they scored six, they had used all services during ANC. In so doing, the responses of the individual components were summed up to generate the outcome variable. Finally, the women who received all six components were coded as received good-quality ANC services.12

sec.title: Independent variables
sec.p: We examined independent variables at two levels. Level 1; included individual-level factors, which were participants’ responses to a survey on personal factors and characteristics of household such as maternal age (15–24, 25–34 and ≥35 years), women’s education (no education, primary, secondary and higher), marital status (ever married and never married), household wealth status (poorest, poorer, middle, richer and richest), working status (working or not working), media exposure (no and yes), parity (categorised as primiparous, multiparous and grand multiparous), ever had a terminated pregnancy (yes and no), pregnancy intention (wanted and unwanted), number of ANC (<4 and ≥4), time of first ANC initiation (timely and delayed) and perception of distance from the health facility (big problem and not a big problem).

Level 2 included community-level factors such as place of residence (rural and urban), community education (low and high), community wealth (low and high) and community media (low and high) exposure. The DHS does not collect data on some community-level variables. Therefore, community-level variables such as community education, community wealth and community media exposure were derived/aggregated from the individual-level data.

sec.title: Operational definitions
sec.p: ANC was defined as a health check-up by health professionals such as doctors, nurses, nurse/midwives, auxiliary midwives and others (health officers and health extension workers) during pregnancy.
Media exposure was coded as ‘yes’ if respondents were exposed to at least one of the media; radio, magazine/newspaper or television and ‘no’ otherwise.
Timing of the first ANC was categorised as timely if the first contact of ANC occurred within 12 weeks of gestation and delayed if the first contact of ANC occurred after 12 weeks of gestation.

Community-level education refers to the proportion of women in the community who have completed primary and above educational levels. It was categorised as low if less than 50% of women in the community had attended at least primary education and high if ≥50% of women in the community had attended at least primary education.

Community wealth was computed from the household wealth and defined as the proportion of women in the community who had the top three wealth quantiles (middle, richer and richest). It was categorised as low if <50% of women in the community were from households with the middle quintile and high if ≥50% of women in the community were from households with at least the middle quintile.
Community media exposure refers to the proportion of women in the community who had exposure to at least one type of media (radio, newspaper or television).
It was categorised as low if <50% of women in the community had media access and high if ≥50% of women in the community had media access.

sec.title: Data management and analysis
sec.p: We pooled the data from the 31 sub-Saharan African countries together after extracting the variables using Stata V.17.0. Before the commencement of data analysis, the dataset was weighted using sampling weight to account for differences due to undersampling and oversampling as per the survey design and restore the survey’s representativeness. The distribution of participants’ characteristics was examined using frequencies. The pooled quality of ANC with the 95% CI was reported using a forest plot. The spatial variation of the quality of ANC was presented by using ArcMap. In addition, for the determinants, we fitted multilevel multivariable logistic regression (both fixed and random effects) in order to account for the variability between clusters.

sec.title: Modelling approaches
sec.p: A two-level multilevel logistic regression analysis was fitted to assess individual-level and community-level determinants of the quality of ANC, for which women (level 1) were clustered within their communities (level 2). Four models were fitted, the null model with no explanatory variables to assess total variance between communities, model I with only individual-level determinants, model II included community-level determinants and model III with all individual and community-level determinants. Bivariable analysis was performed to select eligible variables for multivariable analysis, and variables with p value≤0.2 were eligible and selected for the multivariable analysis. Finally, in the multivariable analysis, the ORs and its 95% CI were used to report the statistical significance of the fixed effect of independent variables. The statistical software package Stata V.14.0 was used for all statistical analyses.

sec.title: Measures of variation (random effects) and model comparison
sec.p: Variation was observed through area variance with corresponding 95% CI, the intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC), the median OR (MOR) and the proportional change in variance (PCV). Deviance was used to test the goodness-of-fit of each model, with a lower value representing a closer model fit. Accordingly, model III (individual+community) was the best fit model for this study.

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: Neither patients nor the public were involved in the design, conduct, reporting or dissemination of this research.

sec.title: Background characteristics of study participants
sec.p: In this study, a total weighted sample of 438 449 women of reproductive age was included. The majority of the study participants had wanted pregnancies (67.1%) and had ever been married (72.20%). About 40% of study participants initiated the first ANC visit within 12 weeks of gestation, and 37.38% had at least four ANC visits. Nearly 70% of women had exposure to the media. Almost 61% of participants were rural residents (table 2).

caption.title: Frequency distribution of background characteristics of the study participants

sec.title: Components of ANC
sec.p: In SSA, blood pressure measurement is the most offered component (88.1%), ranging from 48.8% in Burundi to 99.1% in The Gambia. Also, 78% of pregnant women received iron supplements in SSA, which varied from 45.4% in Ethiopia to 96.9% in Zambia. The least offered component of ANC was the provision of Tetanus vaccination (44.8 %). It varied from the lowest of 19.7% in Comoros to the highest of 85.4% in Burundi (table 3). As presented in figure 2, only 15.00% (95% CI: 12.00 to 18.00%) of pregnant women received good-quality ANC service in SSA. In the SDG era, nearly 18% of pregnant women received good-quality ANC in SSA.

caption.title: Components of antenatal care received among women who had at least one ANC visit

fn.p: ANC, antenatal care; DR Congo, Democratic Republic of the Congo; SSA, sub-Saharan Africa.

caption.title: Proportion of quality of antenatal care services in 31 sub-Saharan African countries. MDG, Millennium Development Goal; SDG, Sustainable Development Goal.

sec.title: Spatial variation of poor quality ANC among pregnant women in SSA
sec.p: The highest proportion of poor quality of ANC among pregnant women in SSA was spatially distributed in Burundi, Cameroon, Gabon, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, Namibia, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe; while Angola, Chad, Congo Democratic Republic, Comoros, Guinea, Madagascar, Mali, Niger and Senegal had the lowest proportion of poor quality of ANC (figure 3).

caption.title: Spatial distribution of poor quality of antenatal care among pregnant women in sub-Saharan Africa, 2023. Source: United Nations Geoscheme for Africa, 2013.

sec.title: Random parameter estimation and model selection
sec.p: As described in the Methods and materials section, ICC, MOR and PCV were computed to measure the variation in the quality of ANC across clusters. As shown in table 4, in the null model, significant variation in the quality of ANC among pregnant women across clusters (σ2=0.16, 95% CI 0.14 to 0.19) was observed, justifying the use of multilevel analysis for modelling. In the null model, the ICC was 4.6%, suggesting that the variation in the quality of ANC may be attributable to unobserved community factors.

caption.title: Multilevel logistic regression analysis for determinants of quality of antenatal care service

fn.p: Model I: model that includes only individual-level determinants, model II: model that includes only community-level determinants and model III: model that includes both individual-level and community-level determinants.
ANC, antenatal care; AOR, adjusted OR; ICC, intraclass correlation coefficient; LL, log-likelihood; MOR, median OR; PCV, proportional change.

sec.p: Controlling for the individual and community-level factors slightly reduced the proportion of variance in the quality of ANC between communities since ICC between communities dropped slightly from the null model to model III. In comparison with the null model and model III, the MOR showing the effects of community heterogeneity was 1.46 and 1.18, respectively. In the final model (model III), as indicated by the PCV, 81.3% of the variation in the quality of ANC across communities was explained by both individual and community-level factors. Besides, model fitness was checked using deviance. Model III was the best-fitted model since it has the lowest deviance (20 780) value and explained more variability of the quality of ANC (PCV=81.3%). Therefore, all interpretations and conclusions of results were thus based on model III.

sec.title: Factors associated with the quality of ANC
sec.p: Educational status, maternal age, time of ANC initiation, number of ANC contacts, wealth index, media exposure, residence, parity, distance from a health facility, pregnancy intention, community education, community wealth and community media exposure were entered into the multilevel multivariable logistic analysis and identified as determinants affecting the quality of ANC. The odds of receiving good-quality ANC were 1.17 (AOR 1.17; 95% CI 1.07 to 1.29) and 1.18 (AOR 1.18; 95% CI 1.03 to 1.35) times higher among women aged 25–34 years and ≥35 years as compared with women aged 15–24 years. The odds of receiving good-quality ANC were 1.26 (AOR 1.26; 95% CI 1.14 to 1.39) for mothers who had secondary education as compared with those without formal education. The odds of receiving good-quality ANC among women who reside in urban areas were 50% higher (AOR 1.50; 95% CI 1.38 to 1.64) as compared with women who reside in rural areas. Likewise, the odds of receiving good-quality ANC were higher among women who had ≥4 ANC visits (AOR 1.63; 95% CI 1.50 to 1.76), exposed to mass media (AOR 1.11; 95% CI 1.03 to 1.21), living in a community with high educational level (AOR 1.20; 95% CI 1.10 to 1.30) and living in a community with high media exposure (AOR 1.14; 95% CI 1.05 to 1.24). Women who started ANC after 12 weeks of gestation had lower odds of receiving good-quality ANC as compared with those who initiated ANC before 12 weeks of gestation (AOR 0.65; 95% CI 0.61 to 0.71) (table 4).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Using a large-scale nationally representative data, this study investigates the magnitude and determinants of the quality of ANC in sub-Saharan African countries. Our study indicated that pooled prevalence of good-quality ANC was 15.0% (95% CI=12.0% and 18.0%) in SSA, with the highest in Zambia 41.0% (95% CI=40.0% and 43.0%) and the lowest in Zimbabwe 1.0% (95% CI=0.0% to 1.0%). This finding is lower than the prevalence reported by a study in LMICs of 25.2%.42 This variation may be attributed to differences in survey years, the availability of maternal health services across SSA43 44 and the varying approaches to assess quality ANC service. For instance, some studies evaluated quality using only three ANC components,42 whereas the present study considers six ANC components. Additionally, a study in Zimbabwe revealed that there was insufficient provision of antenatal screening tests and interventions because of economic fragility.45 Despite a shortage of professional healthcare staff, Zambia has reported good attendance of ANC services with better economic status for infrastructure and process of care.46 47

Consequently, there was notable spatial diversity in the prevalence of poor ANC service quality across the sub-Saharan African countries among pregnant women. Besides, the highest proportion of poor quality ANC service was identified in Zimbabwe, Tanzania, Chad, Namibia, Burundi, Ethiopia and Togo, whereas the lowest proportion was observed in Zambia, Benin, Rwanda, Burkina Faso and Senegal. A possible explanation could be the national and regional differences in maternal healthcare services availability. Compared with other regions, these areas with a high proportion of poor ANC quality in the sub-Saharan African nations have limited access to infrastructure and health services.48

In a multilevel logistic regression model, this study found that educational status, age, media exposure, number of ANC, the timing of ANC initiation, residence, community education and community media exposure were significantly associated with the quality of ANC in SSA.

In this study, women’s education was positively associated with the quality of ANC. This is congruent with the study conducted in Ethiopia,30 Kenya,1 Nigeria,7 Ghana,28 India31 and Nepal.12 The possible explanation could be that the educational status of women is strongly associated with increased knowledge about maternal healthcare and the most appropriate services for their needs.49 50 Educated mothers are more likely to have decision-making power within the household, and greater confidence and capability to make decisions regarding their own health and their neonates.51 In addition, educated mothers are more likely to have a positive perception of the quality of ANC than uneducated mothers. Hence, this finding implies the need to strengthen the policies aimed at improving the level of education, which is likely to improve the quality of the ANC.52 For SSA, this is particularly very important, where 35.1% of women never attended education and only 29.8% of women completed secondary and above level of education. Education of girls could have both short-term and long-term effects by increasing the knowledge of women regarding reproductive health services and improved utilisation of quality maternal healthcare.53 54

Women exposed to mass media were more likely to receive good-quality ANC than those not exposed to mass media. This finding is supported by previous studies conducted elsewhere.18 55 A study revealed that women who had newspaper exposure at least once a week were associated with higher odds of using the quality of ANC.55 Similarly, Joshi et al reported that women in Nepal who were exposed to television at least once a week had 10% higher odds of receiving quality ANC compared with mothers with no TV exposure.12 This might be because women who are exposed to media have better awareness and information on the availability and benefits of maternal healthcare services. Evidence showed that policies should consider using mass media as a critical source to disseminate information on maternal health globally, especially in LMICs.5658

A higher quality of ANC was observed among women in the richer wealth quantile. This is in line with the studies conducted in Kenya,1 Nigeria,7 Ghana,33 India,31 Bangladesh,18 Nepal12 and LMICs.32 Although ANC is an exempted service given to all pregnant women, this study unexpectedly found that women from households with higher socioeconomic status were more likely to receive good-quality ANC. This disparity may be the hidden costs associated with accessing care such as transportation expenses, as well as indirect costs like time away from household duties and work obligations, which can hinder timely and adequate utilisation of ANC services.59 Therefore, women with higher socioeconomic status are more likely to be able to pay for direct costs such as transportation costs and fulfil household and work obligations. This enables women to receive quality ANC than their counterparts.

Delayed initiation of ANC was negatively and significantly associated with the quality of ANC, in agreement with studies from Nigeria,7 Ghana33 and LMICs.32 Women who initiate ANC within 12 weeks of gestational age are more likely to complete the recommended optimum ANC visits.60 61 Consistent with previous studies,7 30 32 33 35 36 we also found a significant positive association between the frequency of ANC visits and the quality of ANC. This is due to the fact that women with more ANC contacts got more health-related information from health professionals, which in turn resulted in positive health-seeking behaviour of mothers.

Also, women who started ANC within 12 weeks of gestation would get adequate time to take two or more tetanus toxoid immunisation based on the schedule prior to giving birth. The WHO recommends that every pregnant woman should book ANC before 12 weeks of gestation and receive at least four ANC contacts during pregnancy to receive optimal care.62

As observed in previous studies,712 18 3133 our findings also revealed higher odds of quality ANC among women who reside in urban areas than in rural areas. The potential reasons why rural residents are less likely to receive maternal health services and person-centred care are described in detail elsewhere.6366 These reasons include a lack of adequate health facilities as well as qualified health personnel and a lack of infrastructure (eg, road conditions, transport). Moreover, women residing in rural areas have low educational status and low knowledge of maternal health services.67

The current study reveals that the quality of ANC was higher among women residing in communities with a high percentage of educated women. Additionally, women living in communities with high media exposure had higher odds of quality of ANC. However, a study conducted in Ethiopia reported an insignificant association between the quality of ANC and community-level education, and community-level mass media exposure.68 A higher level of education and media exposure among women in a community changes the social dynamics and creates opportunities for women to use maternal healthcare services. Therefore, health professionals should provide continuous health education in the form of maternal education focused on maternal healthcare-seeking behaviour. This could be strengthened by partnering with local media houses (radio stations) and special health promotion in these communities during home visits and ANC contacts to promote the importance of the quality of ANC.

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: This study had substantial strengths. First, it used nationally representative data from multiple countries and applied appropriate multilevel statistical analysis. Second, to the best of our knowledge, it is the first study to explore community-level determinants that affect the quality of ANC in SSA.

Apart from its strengths, this study has some drawbacks that should be noted. The cross-sectional nature of the DHS surveys limits the ability to infer causal relationships, even though associations have been established. The reliance on self-reported data may also introduce recall and social desirability bias. Another limitation is that the DHS dataset provides more comprehensive information and misses important contextual factors like health worker quality, facility readiness and cultural practices that may significantly affect the quality of ANC services. Moreover, due to the secondary nature of data, we did not include some determinants which may influence the quality of ANC such as the provider’s perspective, transportation or women’s networks, and local cultural norms and beliefs. Thus, using a qualitative study is more helpful to understand the quality of ANC from the perspective of healthcare providers and cultural norms and beliefs. Besides, the range of services we analysed is not comprehensive due to data availability in all countries. Nonetheless, we believe that the selected services, namely monitoring of blood pressure, tetanus toxoid immunisation, urine analysis, blood sample test, iron supplementation and deworming are of great importance in providing quality ANC.

sec.title: Conclusion and recommendations
sec.p: This study showed that the quality of ANC per WHO recommendation is low in SSA. Both individual and community-level factors play a vital role in determining the quality of ANC. Women aged 24–34 years or ≥35 years, attended secondary education, resided in urban areas, had ≥4 ANC contacts, were exposed to media, came from communities with a high percentage of educated individuals and from communities with a high percentage of media exposure were positively associated with receiving quality ANC. Hence, this study will help policymakers to design interventions at individual and community levels to improve the quality of ANC and could be used as a baseline for interventional studies on the quality of ANC. Therefore, the coordinated efforts needed to upgrade the quality of ANC in SSA, improving women’s education, increasing access to mass media exposure, encouraging timely initiation of ANC and increasing the frequency of ANC contacts are vital. Special attention should be given to regions identified as having poor quality of ANC service by allocating more resources, improving infrastructure and deploying skilled health workers in these areas. Increasing awareness of the importance of comprehensive ANC through community outreach programmes is also crucial, especially in rural and less educated population. Moreover, the National Ministry of Health should ensure that health facilities are equipped with essential supplies, trained personnel and standardised protocols to deliver quality ANC, and encouraging the participation of partners and community leaders in maternal health initiatives can increase support for women to access timely and quality ANC. Further strategies to improve the quality of care should focus on upgrading education and media exposure at the community level.
Finally, future research should aim to implement DHS surveys more uniformly across countries to enable more accurate temporal and spatial comparisons.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We thank the Measure Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) programme, which granted permission to use DHS data.

fn.p: Funding: The authors have not declared a specific grant for this research from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
Prepublication history for this paper is available online. To view these files, please visit the journal online (https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2024-088031).
Patient consent for publication: Not applicable.

Ethics approval: Ethical approval and participant consent were not required because the study was a secondary data analysis of survey data from the DHS programme that was made publicly available. We sent a formal request to DHS programme, and permission was granted to download and use the data for our study from http://www.dhsprogram.com.
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.
Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.

Map disclaimer: The depiction of boundaries on this map does not imply the expression of any opinion whatsoever on the part of BMJ (or any member of its group) concerning the legal status of any country, territory, jurisdiction or area or of its authorities. This map is provided without any warranty of any kind, either express or implied.
